raw_text:
The future in your pocket
 
 If you are a geek or gadget fan, the next 12 months look like they are going to be a lot of fun.
 
 The relentless pace of development in the hi-tech world and rampant competition in many of its sectors, particularly among mobile phone firms, all suggests that 2005 is going to be a very good year. To begin with, 2005 will be the year that third-generation (3G) mobile phones become inescapable. The 3 network launched in 2003, Vodafone launched its consumer service in November, Orange followed in early December and T-Mobile and O2 are due to launch in 2005. The main result of these launches will likely be a slew of good deals for consumers as operators try to poach new customers from rivals and convince existing users to trade up.
 
 Already the extra capacity in 3G networks lets 3 offer good deals on voice calls at rates that will probably have to be matched by the other operators. But the shift in technology and low cost of voice calls means that operators lose a significant chunk of their revenue. "Show me an operator that believes their voice business can sustain them, and I'll write their obituary" said Niel Ransom, chief technology officer at Alcatel.
 
 Instead operators are likely to push all other things that 3G phones can do such as video messaging and other multimedia capabilities. Already camera phones look set to challenge digital cameras and are likely to win more fans as multi-megapixel devices go on sale. But 3G will not have everything its own way. It will face competition from emerging technologies such as Wimax. This wireless technology can boost data transmission speeds up to 75 megabits per second and works over distances of up to 30 miles. Kent is likely to be the site of the UK's first Wimax network which is due to go live in 2005 and it could be the way that rural areas get high-speed net access. Analyst firm Telecom View predicts that Wimax will steal a lot of market share from 3G and will be a clear winner. Bob Larribeau, principal analyst at Telecom View, said the better return on investment offered by technologies such as Wimax could dent the possible returns of 3G networks. And the growing ubiquity of wi-fi must not be forgotten either. The technology is popping up in more places than ever and its wider use is only held back by the price differences across countries and suppliers.
 
 Moves to unite mobile and fixed phones look set to get more emphasis in 2005 too.
 
 For a start, BT looks set to roll out its Bluephone project during the next 12 months. The service revolves around a hybrid device that uses the mobile networks when you are out and about but switches back to the fixed line when you are at home. Fixed line phones will also start to get much more serious competition from a technology that has the formidable name of Voice over IP (Voip). Voip routes calls via the net instead of the fixed line phone network. Anyone with a broadband connection, which is now more than 50% of the UK's net using population, can use Voip and could slash their monthly phone bills if they used it. Telecommunications regulator Ofcom has declared 056 to be the area code for Voip calls and 2005 is likely to see a lot more consumer-focused Voip call services starting up. Home broadband services will also start to increase in speed as dwindling numbers of new users signing force the pace of competition. If 2004 has been the year of the portable music player, they 2005 looks like it will be the year of the portable media player. Motorola has just announced a deal with Apple to produce a phone that works with the iTunes service and other hybrid gadgets that sport a big memory and lots of other functions will become commonplace. The pace of advancement in storage media will continue mean that the cost per megabyte of memory will plummet. Some of those devices will sport huge hard drives letting you store more data than you ever wanted or knew you had. Convergence could mean that single-function devices start to dwindle in number. Instead every gadget will be able to do almost anything and communicate almost any way you want. The only downside is that consumers will face a series of tough choices as they are confronted by a bewildering array of gadgets each with an enormous numbers of features and vast data holding capacities. But that is the kind of problem most gadget fans can live with.
llama3.2:1b: The next 12 months will see the rollout of third-generation (3G) mobile phones, which will offer better deals on voice calls as operators try to attract new customers and retain existing ones. The shift to 3G will also lead to increased competition for other features such as video messaging and multimedia capabilities. Additionally, Wimax wireless technology is expected to disrupt the market, offering faster data transmission speeds and wider coverage, while Voip (Voice over IP) technology is gaining traction with its ability to route calls over the internet instead of a fixed line network.
llama3.2:3b: 3G mobile phones will become widespread in 2005, offering good deals to consumers due to increased capacity but reducing revenue for operators. The technology faces competition from emerging technologies like Wimax, which can boost data transmission speeds and may steal market share. Mobile and fixed phone services are also converging, with new hybrid devices and Voip (Voice over Internet Protocol) services emerging. Portable media players will become more common, and advancements in storage media will lead to smaller costs per megabyte of memory, enabling more functions and capabilities in gadgets.
gemma2:2b: 2005 will be a year of exciting developments in mobile technology. 3G phones will become ubiquitous, leading to competitive price wars and greater multimedia capabilities. Wimax will challenge 3G's dominance with its faster speeds, while Wi-Fi continues to gain popularity.  Fixed phone lines will face competition from VoIP technology, which offers cheaper calls via the internet. The convergence of mobile and fixed phone technologies is also expected, driven by hybrid devices like BT's Bluephone. As storage capacity increases, portable media players will become more common, offering vast data storage capabilities in increasingly compact designs.  This increased portability will lead to a wider variety of functions and communication possibilities within a single device.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The future in your pocket: Third-generation (3G) mobile phones set to become ubiquitous, while emerging technologies such as Wimax are expected to revolutionize data transmission speeds.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Geeks and tech enthusiasts anticipate an exciting year in 2005 characterized by rapid technological advancements, especially in mobile phones with 3G capabilities expected to dominate. Operators face competition from emerging technologies like Wimax for increased data speeds and wider use of Wi-Fi. Bluephone technology is set to integrate mobile phone services into home networks, while VoIP offers alternative telecommunication methods for those on broadband connections. The portable media market is anticipated to grow as storage and computing capabilities improve, potentially leading to more devices having multiple functions.
qwen2.5:3b:
The future in your pocket

In 2005, third-generation (3G) mobile phones will dominate as 3 networks expand globally. Operators will likely reduce voice call rates to retain customers and attract new ones by offering additional services like video messaging and multimedia capabilities. Competition from technologies such as WiMax and VoIP could challenge 3G's dominance. Mobile and fixed phone integration is also expected, with BT launching Bluephone and VoIP gaining traction. Portable music players will evolve into portable media players in 2005, and the advancement of storage media will make gadgets capable of almost anything, though this could lead to a bewildering array of choices for consumers.
opencoder:1.5b:
In 2005, technology was undergoing an influx of innovation, with consumers eagerly anticipating the introduction of third-generation mobile phones. However, it wasn't until Niel Ransom, a chief technology officer at Alcatel, who publicly supported the growth of mobile networks that a leap forward was realized, marking the year as an industry leader in the era of 3G.

In this world dominated by conventional tech, mobile phones were only ever seen as an upgrade from their era-2002 analog counterparts. The rise of 3G marked a new era, ushering in a fresh era of digital innovation. Companies like Alcatel and T-Mobile have shown consistent growth in the fast-paced world of smartphone technology.

Alcatel, with its proprietary BT project Bluephone, launched in 2005, which saw their mobile phones turn a profit. The Bluephone offered an innovative Voice over IP service that routed calls via the internet instead of the traditional fixed line phone network, offering superior speed and efficiency for consumers who valued this innovation.

The company also launched its wireless broadband plans, enabling rural areas to enjoy high-speed internet connectivity without the hefty cost associated with a long-distance phone call. This growth in telecommunications helped to reshape consumer behavior and expand the reach of mobile networks.

As technology progressed, the world was increasingly dominating by the rise of Voip, which allows for end-to-end communication over the internet. This service was already at its peak as users could dial and talk through the phone network without needing a fixed line connection. However, consumers would face an array of new device functions and hardware capabilities that they were not accustomed to.

The development in technology also accelerated due to the proliferation of Wi-Fi technology, which offered seamless connectivity with minimal lag or delay. This became increasingly popular as Wi-fi was gaining acceptance worldwide. As Wi-fi grew popularity, it led to the creation of several networks operating in various geographical locations across the globe, bringing an extra advantage for consumers.

The future of mobile devices appears set to take a leap forward, marking a new era with more innovative technology and a fresh approach to consumer connectivity. However, consumers are still faced with choices as they must choose which features to invest in to stay competitive or turn towards alternative technologies.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about 2005 in the mobile phone industry. Let me read through it carefully.

First paragraph talks about the future, emphasizing the good times ahead for 2005 because of 3G. It mentions Vodafone, Orange, T-Mobile, and O2 launching their services in 2005. The main result is good deals but operators lose revenue from cheaper voice calls.

Second part discusses how competitors are using multimedia features like video messaging on 3G networks. Also mentions Wimax as a competitor to 3G due to its higher speeds and range, and how Wi-Fi is becoming more widely used in the UK.

Third paragraph talks about moves to unify mobile and fixed phones, starting with Bluephone projects by BT and Voip services being available. The talk about consumer-focused services like portable media players and convergence devices sounds important for gadget fans.

I should focus on key points: 3G's impact, competitors shifting to video, Wimax, Wi-Fi, unified technology trends, and mobile+fixed phones. Also, mention the growth of Wi-Fi in the UK.

Make sure the summary is concise without losing essential details. Keep it straightforward, only the main ideas as plain text.
</think>

The future of 2005 holds promising signs with 3G networks becoming essential, leading to good deals for operators despite lost revenue from cheaper voice calls. Competitors like Wimax aim to compete with 3G's potential, offering faster speeds and longer distances. Operators will push advanced features like video messaging. Unifying mobile and fixed phones through Bluephone projects andVoip services is gaining traction. Grown-up tech like Wi-Fi in the UK is expanding access, with consumer-focused services and unified devices driving gadget enthusiasts.
tinyllama:1.1b: The future in your pocket looks like it will be full of fun as mobile phone firms prepare to launch new 3G networks, which offer better capacity for voice calls and other multimedia capabilities. But consumers may have to deal with a variety of devices offering everything from video messaging to multi-media capabilities due to the shift in technology and the low cost of VoIP calls. The rise of consumer media players and hybrid devices is expected to increase in 2005, as portable music players also debut. The trend toward convergence and single-function devices could cause a dwindling number of functionalities to appear on GaDgets, but this will offer opportunities for consumers to make more informed choices as they confront an array of GaDgets each with vast data storage capacities.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The future is looking bright for mobile phones in 2005, as they will become even more advanced than today's devices while also having a chance to replace fixed-line telephones and provide unparalleled access to information and services. Here are the key ideas from the text:

1. The future in your pocket: Making a statement about the impact of 3G technology, this sentence tells us that mobile phones will become even more versatile in 2005, making them an indispensable part of our lives.

2. If you are a geek or gadget fan, the summary as plain text will be: "User Summary: Geeks and Gadget Lovers Will Enjoy Future of Mobile Phones." 

3. The future in your pocket: In detailing the key points mentioned above, we get into more detail about how 2005 will see the development and proliferation of mobile phones and how this will impact society.

4. Third-generation (3G) mobile phones become inescapable: This sentence indicates that the next year's phones won't be just minor improvements on today's models but will be the first to feature 3G technology, making them a must-have for consumers.

5. The relentless pace of development in the hi-tech world: The emphasis is on how advances in technology and competition will drive the evolution of mobile phones in the coming years.

6. Geeks and Gadget Lovers will enjoy future of mobile phones: This sentence implies that mobile phones will be a big part of our lives, but it also means that geeks like you and gadget lovers like me will have a lot to look forward to in the coming years.

7. The year 2005 is going to be a very good year: This concludes with an optimistic outlook for what lies ahead in the world of mobile phones, and highlights how these devices are evolving each year.
phi:2.7b: In 2005, there is expected to be a surge in high-tech advancements such as third-generation (3G) mobile phones, which will offer good deals for consumers. With increased capacity, operators could lose revenue from voice calls but instead push other features such as video messaging and multimedia capabilities. However, competition from emerging technologies like Wimax may steal market share. The concept of combining mobile and fixed phones is also gaining traction. Additionally, VoIP technology allows people to make phone calls through the internet and can reduce monthly phone bills for those with broadband connections. Home broadband services are expected to increase in speed, leading to more affordable options for consumers. Portable media players will also become increasingly popular as storage media costs continue to decrease. Devices may even start performing multiple functions, presenting consumers with a wide array of choices.
orca-mini:3b: The future seems to be in your pocket, with the launch of 3G mobile phones, Wimax wireless technology, and a growing ubiquity of Wi-Fi. BT's Bluephone project aims to unite mobile and fixed phones, while Voip calls are becoming more prominent with the increasing popularity of broadband services. Portable music players and media players are also set to become increasingly popular in 2005, with Motorola's deal with Apple and the plummeting cost of storage media. Convergence could lead to a decline in single-function devices, making it difficult for consumers to choose between them. However, with so many gadgets offering almost everything, consumers may find themselves overwhelmed by choice.
hermes3:3b:
2005 mobile future summary:
- 3G phones becoming ubiquitous
- Competition from emerging techs like WiMax
- Growing use of wi-fi
- Focus on uniting mobile and fixed phones, including VoIP services
- Portable media players gaining prominence
- Rapid advancements in storage media
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The upcoming year will be exciting for tech enthusiasts, as third-generation mobile phones become ubiquitous, launching in 2005 with major players like 3, Vodafone, Orange, T-Mobile, and O2 entering the market. This leads to competition and lower voice call revenue for operators, prompting them to focus on additional features such as video messaging and multimedia capabilities. Wimax technology may also challenge 3G, offering faster data transmission speeds. Unifying mobile and fixed phones will gain more importance in 2005, with BT's Bluephone project and Voice over IP (Voip) gaining traction due to increased broadband access. Portable media players, convergence of gadgets, and tough choice options for consumers will be the challenges faced in 2005.
stablelm2:1.6b: In the near future, 3G mobile phone launches are expected to lead to numerous deals for consumers, pushing other technologies such as Wimax and Voip to compete for market share. The emphasis on unifying mobile and fixed phones will also increase, with companies like BT and Voip becoming prominent players. Portable media players, such as those that work with iTunes, will become more common, along with a reduction in the cost of storage media. Convergence means that gadgets will have multiple functions, allowing consumers to make tough choices among an array of devices.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
In 2005, the mobile technology landscape will witness significant advancements and increased competition, offering consumers a plethora of innovative devices and services. The year will mark the widespread adoption of third-generation (3G) mobile phones, which promise improved voice calls at competitive rates, despite operators' revenue loss due to lower call costs. This shift will likely accelerate the growth of multimedia capabilities like video messaging.

3G faces competition from emerging technologies such as Wimax, which can deliver data speeds up to 75 megabits per second over distances of up to 30 miles. Kent is expected to be the first UK location for a Wimax network in 2005, potentially providing rural areas with high-speed internet access and challenging 3G's market share.

The increasing ubiquity of Wi-Fi technology will also impact mobile devices, as its price differences across countries and suppliers gradually disappear. BT is planning to roll out the Bluephone project in 2005, a hybrid device that seamlessly switches between mobile networks and fixed lines based on user location.

Voice over IP (VoIP) services will gain more traction as they allow broadband users to make calls via the internet, potentially reducing phone bills significantly. Ofcom has designated 056 for VoIP calls in 2005, with many new consumer-focused VoIP services expected to launch during this period.

Fixed line phone competition will intensify as VoIP gains popularity, and home broadband speeds are anticipated to increase due to dwindling users. The year of portable music players in 2004 is likely to transition into the era of portable media players, with Motorola's agreement to produce an iTunes-compatible phone being a notable example.

Other hybrid gadgets featuring large memory capacities and diverse functionalities will become more commonplace. The rapid advancement in storage media promises that the cost per megabyte will plummet, enabling devices with massive hard drives for storing vast amounts of data. This convergence trend may lead to a decline in single-function gadgets as every device starts to offer multiple capabilities and communication methods.

However, consumers will encounter a bewildering array of advanced gadgets, each packed with numerous features and extensive storage capacities. The primary downside is that users might face difficult decisions amidst this proliferation of high-tech devices.
chatgpt-4o-latest:

Third-generation (3G) mobile networks will become widespread, with major operators launching services and offering competitive deals. However, the low cost of voice calls will push operators to promote multimedia features like video messaging. 3G will face competition from emerging technologies like Wimax, which offers faster data speeds and broader coverage, potentially challenging 3G’s market share. Wi-Fi will also continue expanding despite pricing inconsistencies. 

Additionally, mobile and fixed-line phone integration will gain traction, with BT launching its Bluephone project, which switches between mobile and fixed networks. Voice over IP (VoIP) will grow, allowing broadband users to cut phone costs, with Ofcom designating 056 as the VoIP area code. Home broadband speeds will increase due to competition. 

Portable media players will rise in popularity, with Motorola partnering with Apple for an iTunes-compatible phone. Storage media will advance, reducing memory costs and enabling devices with vast storage capacities. Convergence will lead to multifunctional gadgets, making single-purpose devices less common. Consumers will face tough choices due to the overwhelming variety of feature-rich gadgets, but tech enthusiasts will likely embrace these developments.
